Can you give some examples?  An empty request is non-sensical.

If we're going to do this (which I'm not convinced we should yet), I'd much rather that we rely on some kind of intrinsic like "all items are std::optional" to determine this rather than giving an explicit option.  Take a look at how the missing parameters are handled for how this would work.  To be more concrete

readJson(res, "foo", std::string, true);
is non-nonsensical, because you're declaring a required parameter, but allowing empty.  At interface level, this shouldn't be allowed.

Also, for the template unpacking to work, you shouldn't add allowEmpty in the middle of the request.

yeah, I am trying to compile it locally and this def not work.

I'll see how to clean it up.

----

Ok, sounds good. That make it easier to maintain it if we can detect if all options are optional. I'll take a look.
wait. This is wrong. how can we check if a property is optional?

Maybe we don't need this? and just have whoever that is reading optional property not use `readJson`?

So they have full control of what it does?

Lets start with why, then we can go to what. Assuming that chicago is asking the same question, it's about unpacking std::vector<nlohmann>, which I agree, should allow optionals, and looks like an oversight.  We probably need to special case the vector case.

> wait. This is wrong. how can we check if a property is optional?

see the IsOptional class up above, but now that I understand this, I don't think this is the same case.  We need IsVector

oh I get it. I was thinking about how I can know if the Redfish response's property is suppose to be optional based on the spec and sutff.

This make more sense. So in a way, how we fetch the data will let us know if it is optional.

um...

I have it setup so that if you are requesting only optional properties and the json is empty then you don't get the error. Maybe I should return true at that point instead of false.
Not sure if IsVector is what we want. PTAL, I added handleEmpty to check if all of the fields are optional. If not, return false.

> Not sure if IsVector is what we want. PTAL


ok, lets start with behavior

readJson(...., "Foo", std::vector<nlohmann::json>)

Should allow empty objects on the sub object, but not on the root object.

readJson(...., "Foo", int64_t)

Should not allow empty objects.  From my perspective, that means we need to use IsVector to determine if we're in a vector subobject, or not.



>I have it setup so that if you are requesting only optional properties and the json is empty then you don't get the error.

That's incorrect.  PATCH with an empty payload is nonsensical, and is the reason this error exists.

PATCH with an empty SUB-object, is fine.

PATCH {}  <--- Should be an error

PATCH {"IpAddresses": [{}]"} <--- should not be an error.

Discussed a bit offline. There are different use cases for readJson.

Actions and Patch.

Will split into different API to for readJsonPatch and readJsonAction.

The only difference between the two at this point is whether or not completely empty is allowed.

- Patch will not support fully empty.
- Action allows it.
isn't this going to set one emptyJSON message per non-optional key?  That doesn't seem right.  I suspect the old logic was more correct.

This will go through all of the requested properties and return false + empty Json message once  if it find a property is not optional.

So this will only set one emptyJSON message.

```
details::handleEmpty(res, val) && details::handleEmpty(res, in...)
```

Once `details::handleEmpty(res, val)` is false, `details::handleEmpty(res, in...)` will not be called.
Looks like this is missing setting messages::emptyJSON?
Done

One thing to point out is that this doesn't fix the behavior with something like

readJson(..... "key", std::vector<nlohmann::json> j)

which should not set an emptyJson message if it hits the sub-key within the list and its empty.
Do you mean that if the Json is empty and that the requested property is a vector, then it shouldn't error out?
Isn't this wrong?  readJsonAction should simply allow empty payloads in all cases.  If parameters are required and not provided, there are more specific error messages we'll produce.

ah, ok. Then I guess we don't need to do handleEmpty at all.

We will let the caller handle the errors.
